assets.headline: Markets Live: ASX closes at 6026
assets.theAbstract: The S&P/ASX 200 has reached a fresh three month high after IT and industrial stocks added to yesterday's bank gains.
assets.liveArticleSummary:
• RBA Governor Philip Lowe's speech sent the Aussie dollar down 
  • Australian banking stocks are down today, after yesterday's massive rise
  • IAG is up 4.5 per cent and Viva Energy is up 14 per cent

relatedPosts.body:
Good morning and welcome to today's Markets Live blog. 

Your editor today is Lucy Battersby with help from fellow journos and wire services. 

This blog is not intended as financial advice.
relatedPosts.extendedAbstract: Good morning and welcome to today's Markets Live blog. Your editor today is Lucy Battersby with help from fellow journos and wire services. This blog is not intended as financial advice.

relatedPosts.body:
IG MARKETS SPONSORED POST

The ASX is set to add to Tuesday's bumper day with futures pointing to gains at the open after a solid night on Wall Street. The bulls keep control: SPI futures are indicating that the ASX200 will climb another 20 points at the open, adding to yesterday's bank-led 1.95 per cent rally. Another solid day on Wall Street can also be pointed-to for the market's start in the green, with US shares continuing their run-higher. Quietness in Asia courtesy of the Chinese New Year holiday has kept some negative headlines way, aiding the bullishness. Global bond markets are steady, gold is off its highs, and credit spreads keep narrowing.

One lesson from financial markets in the last week: no person wants to be the one responsible for making necessary changes to something in the long-term, if it means inflicting pain in the short-term. It's a characteristic of human fallibility and is arguably evidence as to why when crises occur, they tend to hurt more than perhaps what is necessary. There is a parallel with what we've seen in the US in the last 7 days, and what has transpired in Australia this week. In the US, it was US Federal Reserve Chairperson Jerome Powell wilting under the pressure of Wall Street in his bid to normalise interest rates. In Australia, it was the Hayne Royal Commissions failure to make the necessary systemic changes to improve the nation's financial system.

relatedPosts.body:
Commonwealth Bank said its cash earnings from continuing operations rose 1.7 per cent to $4.68 billion in the first half of fiscal 2019, slightly below analysts' consensus estimates. Revenue slid 1.9 per cent to $12.4 billion, with volume growth offset by a net interest margin decline, lower fees and weaker trading conditions. CBA shares closed at $73.60 yesterday. 

Net interest margin was 2.1 per cent, four basis points lower than the same period a year earlier. The bank blamed the margin decline on higher funding costs, the impact of customers switching from interest only to principal and interest and from investor to owner occupied home loans, reduced fixed rate home loan pricing, and home loan competition.

Read the full story by Stephen Miles here

relatedPosts.body:
Virgin Australia has appointed former DP World stevedores and Queensland Rail boss Paul Scurrah to replace John Borghetti as its chief executive. The logistics veteran will take over the top job at Australia's second-largest airline on March 25, Virgin said on Wednesday morning. He will be tasked with stabilising the airline's finances after six unprofitable years. Shares have dropped over that period, from a high of 55 cents in 2015 to a closing price of 18.5 cents yesterday. Virgin in 20 per cent owned by Etihad Airways, 20 per cent owned by Singapore Airlines, 20 per cent by Nanshan Capital, 20 per cent by Chinese conglomerate HNA and 10 per cent owned by Richard Branson's Virgin Models Ltd. 

Mr Scurrah worked at Qantas in the early 1990s, and later at Ansett, where he rose to the position of general manager of sales and marketing during its administration. He later held senior roles at Flight Centre and other travel and tourism operators. Mr Scurrah - whose position as a leading candidate for the top job was revealed exclusively by The Age and SMH in early January - has spent the last seven years in logistics, first at Aurizon and then as head of stevedores DP World Australia, the nation's largest port and supply chain operator.

Read the full story from Patrick Hatch here

relatedPosts.body:
Viva Energy Group (VEA) and Coles Group have extended their alliance for a further ten years to 2029, the companies announced this morning. Viva shares jumped 18.5 per cent this morning to and intra-day high of $2.28, but have since settled back down to $2.16 a 12 per cent rise on yesterday's close. Coles, which demerged from Wesfarmers in November is down 1.8 per cent to $12.50. 

Viva Energy will take responsibility for retail fuel pricing, and collect the fuel margin and store sales royalty, while Coles Express will keep operating the stores at the petrol stations, and collect margin on store sales and a fuel commission. 

Viva will pay Coles a one-off $137 million from debt facilities as part of the deal. It reaffimed earnings guidance and said second half retail earnings will be in line with the first half, which is $322 million, leading a 5.7 per cent increase on the 2018 full year result of $609 million unaudited. Last year Viva also beat its fuel sales guidance, selling 14,046 million litres, compared to expectations of up to 13,945 million litres. Loyalty scheme benefits such as earning flybuys points on fuel sales, and the 4c a litre shopper docket discount, will continue, Coles said.

 

Viva Energy Real Estate Investment Trust (VVR) also released a statement confirming Viva Energy is the tenant at 430 sites owned by its trust.

relatedPosts.body:
Opposition treasury spokesman Chris Bowen has just called a press conference calling on Liberal MP Tim Wilson to resign from his role as chair of the Standing Committee on Economics' Inquiry into the implications of removing refundable franking credits. The inquiry has nearly completed its Public Hearings, with just two more left - in Bondi and Chatswoon this Friday. 

Mr Bowen's call comes after revelations veteran fund manager Geoff Wilson asked for hearings to be scheduled at the same time as of one his own six-monthly investor roadshows. Indeed, Wilson Asset Management's 20 November, 2018, roadshow in Sydney coincided with Mr Wilson's inquiry holding public hearings in Sydney, at 170 Philip Street. 

Read the full story from Eryk Bagshaw here

relatedPosts.body:
Iron ore prices are tipped to temporarily spike above $US100 a tonne after mining giant Vale announced it had been ordered to halt some mining operations following last month's horrific dam collapse in Brazil. News of the stoppage, which emerged from Brazil overnight on Monday, sent shares in Australia's big three iron ore producers, Rio Tinto, BHP and Fortescue Metals Group, up strongly on Tuesday as investors bet they would benefit from a higher commodity price.

Fortescue's stock jumped 4.7 per cent to close at $6, while Rio rose 3 per cent to $89.26 and BHP climbed 1.1 per cent to $35.39. The three Australian miners' market capitalisations have surged about $24.34 billion as the shockwaves from the dam collapse continue to reverberate around global markets. On a full-year basis, the court-ordered halt of some operations at Vale's Brucutu mine could cut the company's iron ore production by 30 million tonnes, with ramifications for global supply and the iron ore price.

Read the full story from Darren Gray here

relatedPosts.body:
Westpac shares are down 52 cents to $26.18, a drop of 2 per cent, after yesterday's 7 per cent rally. The bank is appointing two new non-executive directors to the board who will both become members of its risk and compliance committee. Westpac has chosen Margie Seale, who is an experienced director and comes from the publishing industry, and Steven Harker, who worked for investment banks Morgan Stanley and Barclays. 

Ms Seale currently sits on the board at Scentre Group, Telstra, and Australian Pacific and previously sat on the boards of Ramsay Health Care, Bank of Queensland, and Penguin Random House, where she previously worked as managing director of Random House. Mr Harker worked at Barclays Investment Bank for 15 years before he became chief executive of Morgan Stanley Australia from 1998 to 2016. He is currently a director of The Banking and Finance Oath, The Hunger Project, and ASX Refinitiv Charity Foundation.

relatedPosts.body:
Shares in Insurance Australia Group (IAG) are up 4.6 per cent to $7.64 this morning, the highest price since the end of August, 2018. This morning it announced first-half profit dropped 9.3 per cent, hurt by costly damage from the hailstorm that battered Sydney in December. Net profit fell to $500 million in the six months ended December 31, compared with $551 million in the same period a year earlier.

The company expects "slightly more subdued growth" in the second half of fiscal 2019. The company's interim fully franked dividend is 12 cents a share, down from 14 cents a share in the same period a year earlier.

Read the full story from Stephen Miles here

relatedPosts.body:
The S&P/ASX 200 is currently 17 points higher at 6022.9 points. The information technology sector is up 2.4 per cent and Industrials are up 1.8 per cent. Financials are lagging. With the banks retreating from yesterday's massive gains. The big four are down more than 1 per cent each. 

BHP Group is up 1.1 per cent to $35.78 and IAG is up 5.5 per cent to $7.70. Sydney Airport has climbed 4.1 per cent after the Productivity Commission's report on regulation came out without any surprises.

The big four are down more than 1 per cent each. BHP Group is up 1.1 per cent to $35.78 and IAG is up 5.5 per cent to $7.70. Sydney Airport has climbed 4.1 per cent after the Productivity Commission's report on regulation came out without any surprises.

relatedPosts.body:
Listed motorcycle dealership group MotorCycle Holdings, is down 14.2 per cent to $1.63 today, an all time low. It told the market today that earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation will be between $10 million and $10.5 million for the six months ending 31 December, 2018. Analysts estimated EBITDA would be around $11.4 million, according to data from Bloomberg. 

Chief executive David Ahmet, who also owns 18.4 per cent of shares directly, blamed a "continuing national market decline in new motorcycle sales". The business may sell more used motorcycles to increase turnover and wants to increase its online presence. 

"Our current activities to integrate recent acquisitions, strengthen our management team, improve processes and upgrade systems will ensure the company will benefit from improved market conditions when they return."

The business may sell more used motorcycles to increase turnover and wants to increase its online presence.

relatedPosts.body:
The Australian dollar has taken a dramatic drop in reaction to Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe's speech in Sydney today, falling  0.7 per cent from 72.41 US cents to 71.86 US cents in a matter of seconds. Dr Lowe has suggested rates may need to be cut further. 

 

"Looking forward, there are scenarios where the next move in the cash rate is up and
other scenarios where it is down," he said. "Over the past year, the next-move-is-up scenarios were more likely than the next-move-is-down scenarios. Today, the probabilities appear to be more evenly balanced."

Dr Lowe said much would hinge on the strength of the jobs market, with unemployment now at 5 per cent.

Read the story by Shane Wright here

relatedPosts.body:
Donald Trump's State of the Union Address is about to start. Below is a story from Associated Press about what is expected to happen. 

After two years of bitter partisanship and personal attacks, President Donald Trump will call for unity and cross-party cooperation in Washington during Tuesday's State of the Union address, a message likely to ring hollow with Democrats determined to block his push for a border wall.

Trump's prime-time address comes at a critical moment in his presidency. He pushed his party into a lengthy government shutdown over border security, only to cave to Democrats. With another shutdown deadline looming, the president has few options for getting Congress to fund a border wall, and he risks further alienating his party if he tries to circumvent lawmakers by declaring a national emergency instead.

Trump was not expected to issue the emergency declaration in his speech, in part because he's aware of GOP opposition and wants to avoid being booed in the House chamber. Still, the president planned to hammer his case that the situation at the southern border represents a security crisis for Americans.

"No issue better illustrates the divide between America's working class and America's political class than illegal immigration," Trump will say, according to excerpts released ahead of his address. "Wealthy politicians and donors push for open borders while living their lives behind walls and gates and guards."

As he stands before lawmakers, the president will be surrounded by symbols of his emboldened political opposition. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who was praised by Democrats for her hard-line negotiating during the shutdown, will sit behind the president as he speaks. Some Democratic women will be wearing white, the color favored by early 20th-century suffragettes. And several senators running for president will be in the audience, including Sens. Kamala Harris of California and Cory Booker of New Jersey.

For a time, it was unclear if Trump's annual address to Congress would happen. He'd been scheduled to speak to lawmakers last week, but Pelosi forced him to postpone while the shutdown persisted. White House officials said Trump planned to highlight areas where he believes he can work with Democrats, including infrastructure and prescription drug pricing.

While Trump was still putting the final touches on the speech Tuesday afternoon, he was expected to use some of his televised address to showcase a growing economy. Despite the shutdown, the U.S. economy added a robust 304,000 jobs in January, marking 100 straight months of job growth. That's the longest such period on record.

Trump and his top aides have also hinted that he is likely to use the address to announce a major milestone in the fight against the Islamic State group in Syria. Despite the objections of some advisers, Trump announced in December that he was withdrawing U.S. forces in Syria.

In a weekend interview with CBS, Trump said efforts to defeat the IS group were "at 99 percent right now. We'll be at 100." Foreign policy has been another area where Republicans have increasingly been willing to distance themselves from the president. Several leading GOP lawmakers have sharply criticized his plans to withdraw from Syria, as well as from Afghanistan. Trump, in excerpts of his address, defended his moves, declaring: "Great nations do not fight endless wars."

He pushed his party into a lengthy government shutdown over border security, only to cave to Democrats. With another shutdown

relatedPosts.body:
The information technology sector is outperforming today with a rise of 2.6 per cent compared to S&P/ASX 200 index gains of 0.5 per cent. The rise is being driven by a 5 per cent rise in Altium shares to $26.83, a 4 per cent gain in Afterpay Touch to $17.54, and a 2.6 per cent rise in Computershare to $18.24. Xero and Link Administration, which are heavy stocks within the index, are also higher. 

The industrial sector is also outperforming, up 2 per cent, thanks to gains in Sydney Airport, Transurban, and Brambles.

relatedPosts.body:
IAG is up 33 cents today to $7.64, a one-day gain of 4.6 per cent and the highest price since August. Senior analyst and head of research at Bell Potter, TS Lim says this morning's results show the company is in a good position even though net profits dropped by $51 million to $500 million for the half year period. 

"The underlying result is good, top line growth is strong [and] costs are coming down. The underlying margin went up by 300 basis points," he tells me. "When you look at the underlying profit of the company it is actually pretty strong." 

Mr Lim says they probably cut the dividend because of the impact of December hail storms, but have lots of capital.

relatedPosts.body:
Greencross shareholders have voted in favour of a takeover by private equity firm TPG at $5.55 per share.

Greencross expects to get a court hearing on 11 February, next Monday, to get approval with the shares suspended from close of trading that day. A special dividend will be announced on 13 February and paid on 20 February and the scheme will be implemented on 27 February.

A special dividend will be announced on 13 February and paid on 20 February and the scheme will be implemented on 27 February.

relatedPosts.body:
The S&P/ASX 200 is still rising in afternoon trading and currently at 6037.5 points. It hit an intra-day high of 6042 after hitting a low of 5990 shortly after opening. 

Today's rise is being supported by BHP, up 1.2 per cent to $35.83, and IAG's 4.9 per cent rise to $7.66. Macquarie Group is also adding points to the index, up 2.2 per cent to $121.07 - the first time it has been over $120 since 12 November, 2018.

Macquarie Group is also adding points to the index, up 2.2 per cent to $121.07 - the first time it has been over $120 since 12 November, 2018.

relatedPosts.body:
Coles has been overcharging for petrol because it controlled the pump price, it has emerged in news of its re-written deal with Viva Energy. This means petrol prices are set to fall at Coles Express services stations after Viva Energy took control of petrol prices. Coles shares are down 2.2 per cent to $12.45. The supermarket giant's fuel sales have been falling because its pump prices were too high under its agreement with Viva Energy, and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has signalled it out as the most expensive fuel retailer in the country.

Viva Energy chief executive Scott Wyatt said by shifting the control of the pump from Coles back to Viva the fuel price would likely drop. "Historically, Coles set the retail pump price but we felt in order to grow our business we had to have control over how the pump price is set," Mr Wyatt said. "Part of this deal is focusing on improving our fuel offer and improving the competitiveness of pricing."

On Wednesday, Coles said that earnings from its Express division would fall almost 70 per cent this year and revealed it had signed a new agreement with Viva locking in the partnership to 2029. Under the new deal, Viva will operate and set prices at the bowser. Coles will take a commission on each litre of petrol Viva sells, and run the convenience store operations at each service station. Viva Energy shares are up 13.2 per cent to $2.17. 

Read the full story from Patrick Hatch here

relatedPosts.body:
Chief investment officer at Watermark Funds Management (which recently decided to pivot back to Australian-only shares), Justin Braitling, says the fundamental outlook for Australian bank stocks still is not good. They face a lot of risks if Labor wins government this year, he says, because they are seen as a "soft target". 

"There is a sense of relief that potentially the credit squeeze will be over now," he says, referring to the banks tightening lending standards in response to the banking royal commission. "I think we need to get through the next couple of weeks of results before we crack the champagne corks for the consumer sector. We are expecting some disappointing results." 

Mr Braitling says consumer discretionary companies are likely to have cautious outlook commentary because of the slowing economic growth.

relatedPosts.body:
There's a recommendation on executive remuneration in the final report of the financial services royal commission that institutional shareholders probably aren't going to be happy to see being put on the reform agenda, writes Stephen Bartholomeusz. 

The Royal Commissioner, Kenneth Hayne, has recommended the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority set limits on the use of financial metrics within their long-term variable remuneration schemes for senior executives. In recent years there has been significant institutional push-back against attempts by bank and other boards to introduce non-financial metrics into the hurdles for their variable remuneration plans. The preference of most institutional shareholders, for obvious and self-interested reasons, is to reward executives with incentives tied largely and directly to maximising shareholder returns.

Read the full column here

In recent years there has been significant institutional push-back against attempts by bank and other boards to introduce non-financial metrics into the hurdles for their variable remuneration plans. relatedPosts.body:
The S&P/ASX 200 has closed at 6026, 20 points higher than it opened but lower than an intra-day high of 6042 reached around lunch time. But it has managed to stay above the 6000 level. 

The most points were contributed by BHP, IAG, Macquarie, Rio Tino, and Sydney Airport. Meanwhile points were subtracted by declines in CSL, the big four banks, Coles, and APA Group. 

Information technology was the best performing sector, up 2.3 per cent against a 0.3 per cent rise in the ASX 200. This was driven by a 2.5 per cent gain in Computershare and a 2.7 per cent gain in Xero, which dominate that index.

Meanwhile points were subtracted by declines in CSL, the big four banks, Coles, and APA Group. Information technology was the best performing sector, up 2.3 per cent against a 0.3 per cent rise in the ASX 200. relatedPosts.body:
That is all from us today, thank you for your time and your comments. Half year reports are due tomorrow from AGL Energy, News Corp, Mirvac Group, and Downer EDI. 

We will be back in the morning. Good night.
relatedPosts.extendedAbstract: That is all from us today, thank you for your time and your comments. Half year reports are due tomorrow from AGL Energy, News Corp, Mirvac Group, and Downer EDI. We will be back in the morning. Good night.

overrides.overrideAbstract: The S&P/ASX 200 has reached a fresh three month high after IT and industrial stocks added to yesterday's bank gains.
